children.name: when sb accidentally falls from a standing position
fall
children.definition: to accidentally fall from a standing position: ngã
examples: ▪ She was going up the stairs when she fell.
▪ George held on tightly, afraid that he might fall.

children.name: fall down the stairs/steps etc ngã xuống cầu thang, bậc thang
examples: ▪ There was concern for the Queen Mother yesterday after she fell down a short flight of steps at the airport.

children.name: fall over/down
children.definition: to fall onto thegroundfrom a standing position:

children.name: ngã xuống đất
examples: ▪ Ben fell down and scraped his knee.
▪ Beginning skiers can expect to fall down a lot.
▪ The pavement was slippery and it was easy to fall over.

children.name: have a fall
children.definition: if someone, especially an old person, has a fall, they fall and hurt themselves: té ngã (người già yếu)
examples: ▪ My neighbour has had a fall and broken a rib.
▪ Grandma had a bad fall in the snow that winter.

children.name: tumble
children.definition: to fall quickly down a slope or down stairs, rolling over and over and unable to stop: lộn nhào

children.name: tumble down/off/into etc lộn nhào xuống, khỏi, vào
examples: ▪ She tumbled down the stairs and landed in a heap at the bottom.
▪ A bus veered off the road and tumbled down the hill into the river below.

children.name: fall flat on your face
children.definition: to fall over suddenly so that you are lying on your front on the ground, especially in a way that makes you look funny: té lăn quay
examples: ▪ She fell flat on her face getting out of the car.
▪ The last time I wore high-heeled shoes I fell flat on my face outside a restaurant.

children.name: collapse
children.definition: to fall suddenly and heavily onto the ground, into a chair etc, because of tiredness, illness, or injury: ngã khuỵ
examples: ▪ One of the horses collapsed from exhaustion after the race.
collapse[singular noun] ngã khuỵ
▪ After Stephen’s sudden collapse during the meeting, he was rushed to the hospital.

children.name: collapse on ngã khuỷ lên
examples: ▪ Cohen was hospitalized after he collapsed on the floor and briefly lost consciousness.

children.name: collapse into ngã khuỵ vào
examples: ▪ Milligan collapsed into a chair, sighing deeply.

children.name: keel over
children.definition: to suddenly fall to the ground, because you are ill or have had a shock: ngất xỉu
examples: ▪ She’d been complaining of a headache all morning, and suddenly she just keeled over.
▪ Carson keeled over and died in front of the nightclub after taking a number of illegal drugs.

children.name: go head over heels
children.definition: to fall forward with so much force that you roll over: ngã sầm
examples: ▪ She slipped on the polished floor and went head over heels.
▪ Shelly’s horse stepped into soft sand and went down, horse and rider going head over heels in a cloud of dust.

children.name: when an upright object, a building, a wall, etc falls
fall
examples: đổ, sụp
▪ She was playing just yards from where the building fell.
fall across/onto/on top of độ sụp xuống, lên phía trên của
▪ A tree had fallen across the road and blocked it.
fall off/out of/from đổ ra khỏi, từ
▪ The days were getting shorter and the leaves had started falling from the trees
▪ I can’t find my passport - it must have fallen out of my pocket.
fallen[adjective only before noun] đổ
▪ Fallen trees blocked the railway tracks.

children.name: fall over
children.definition: if a tall object falls over, it falls onto its side from an upright position: ngã xuống
examples: ▪ That bookcase looks as if it’s about to fall over.
▪ There was no wind; the tree just fell over.

children.name: fall down
children.definition: if abuilding,wall, orfencefalls down, part or all of it falls to the ground, because it is inbadconditionor because it has beendamaged:

children.name: đổ sụp
examples: ▪ A boy was injured yesterday when part of a wall fell down near to where he was playing.
▪ A large tree fell down during a windstorm and damaged our car.

children.name: collapse
children.definition: if abuilding,walletc collapses, it suddenly falls down, especially because of asuddenpressure:

children.name: đổ sập
examples: ▪ Our tent collapsed in the middle of the night.
▪ The building was badly damaged in the explosion, and rescue workers are worried that it may collapse.
▪ Minutes later the second tower collapsed.

children.name: fall in
children.definition: if a roof falls in, it falls to the ground inside the building: rơi
examples: ▪ During the hurricane the roof fell in.

children.name: fall in on rơi lên
examples: ▪ We need to fix the ceiling before it falls in on us.

children.name: cave in
children.definition: if a roof, wall etc caves in, it suddenly and heavily falls inwards especially because it is weak and in bad condition: sụp
examples: ▪ The roof has caved in, so the whole building has been declared unsafe.

children.name: cave in on sụp xuống
examples: ▪ Wooden beams support the roof, preventing it from caving in on the miners.

children.name: topple over
children.definition: if something topples over, it moves unsteadily backwards and forwards then falls to the ground: sụp đổ
examples: ▪ The little boy put one more brick on the tower and it toppled over.
▪ That plant’s going to topple over if you don’t put it in a bigger pot.

children.name: tip over
children.definition: to suddenly turn and fall to the ground as a result of not being properly balanced: té nhào
examples: ▪ I sat on the edge of the table, and the whole thing tipped over.
▪ The fire started when a lamp tipped over and ignited a cloth sofa.

children.name: knock sb over/down
children.definition: knock somebody over/knock somebody down  to push or hit someone hard, so that they fall to the ground:
examples: dẩy, húc, đánh ngã ..

children.name: knock somebody over/down đánh gục ai đó
examples: ▪ Careful where you’re going! You nearly knocked me over!

children.name: ▪ In the rush to get out of the building, she was knocked down.knock down/over somebody
examples: ▪ Some of the bigger boys purposely knock over the smaller ones.

children.name: trip/trip up [UK]
children.definition: to make someone fall or almost fall by putting yourfootor another object in their way:

children.name: đạp ngã
examples: ▪ One of the runners claimed she had been tripped.

children.name: trip somebody up đạp ai đó ngã
examples: ▪ One man tripped me up and the other one grabbed my handbag.

children.name: push sb over
children.definition: push somebody over  to deliberately push someone with your hand so that they fall to the ground: đẩy ai đó ngã
examples: ▪ Another little kid came and pushed him over onto the grass.

children.name: knock sb to the ground
children.definition: knock somebody to the ground  to hit someone so hard that they lose their balance and fall to the ground: đánh ngã xuống đất
examples: ▪ A teenage boy knocked him to the ground and ran off with his briefcase.

children.name: make st fall or let it fall
drop
children.definition: to stop holding something so that it falls, especiallyaccidentally:

children.name: đánh rơi
examples: ▪ Watch you don’t drop that box - it’s very heavy.
▪ Her hands shake constantly and she keeps dropping things.
▪ You dropped your toy. Do you want it back?

children.name: drop something on/onto something đánh rơi cái gì lên cái gì
examples: ▪ Margaret dropped the letters onto her desk.

children.name: knock over
children.definition: to hit something so that it falls onto its side from an upright position, especially when you do thisaccidentally:
examples: làm đổ
knock something over làm cái gì đổ
▪ Be careful or you’ll knock the vase over.
knock over something làm đổ cái gì
▪ He bumped into the table and knocked over the candle.

children.name: spill
children.definition: to accidentally let liquid, powder, or small pieces of something fall onto a surface and spread out over it:
examples: làm tràn, đánh đổ ( nước )
▪ Oops, I just spilled my water.
spill something down/all over/onto something làm tràn cái gì xuống, lên khắp, vào cái gì
▪ ‘How was the party?’ ‘OK, but some idiot spilled wine all over my new dress.’
▪ Aaron spilled all the popcorn on the floor.

children.name: tip over
children.definition: to make something fall over, usually accidentally, by making it lose balance: ngã nhào

children.name: tip something over làm ngã nhào cái gì
examples: ▪ The cat managed to tip the Christmas tree over.

children.name: tip over something ngã nhào vào cái gì
examples: ▪ He accidentally tipped over a candle, and the tablecloth caught fire.

children.name: overturn
children.definition: to make something fall on its side or turn something over completely, especially by pushing it very hard: đẩy ngược
examples: ▪ The wind was so strong that it overturned dustbins and wrecked fences.
▪ Protestors overturned cars and set fire to them.

children.name: upset
children.definition: to accidentally knock or push something over, so that its contents fall out and spread over a wide area: đánh đổ
examples: ▪ One of the kids upset a bottle of water on the table.

children.name: to almost fall from a standing position
tripalsotripoverBritish
children.definition: toaccidentallyhit something with your foot when you are walking or running, so that you fall or nearly fall:

children.name: vấp chân
examples: ▪ I didn’t push him - he tripped.
▪ She’d had quite a lot to drink and kept tripping over.

children.name: trip over vấp vào
examples: ▪ Pick up that box -- someone might trip over it.

children.name: trip on vấp lên
examples: ▪ Her medical problems began when she tripped on a rug and broke her hip.

children.name: trip and fall vấp và té
examples: ▪ One boy tripped and fell into the water.

children.name: slip
children.definition: toaccidentallyslide on a wet or smooth surface, so that you fall or nearly fall:

children.name: trượt chân
examples: ▪ Be careful you don’t slip - the floor’s wet.

children.name: slip on trượt trên
examples: ▪ She slipped on the icy sidewalk and grabbed Will’s arm to steady herself.

children.name: slip and fall trượt và té ngã
examples: ▪ I walked slowly through the mud, trying not to slip and fall.

children.name: stumble
children.definition: to nearly fall down when you are walking or running, because you do not put your foot down carefully or because something is in the way:

children.name: suýt ngã , sẩy chân
examples: ▪ In her hurry, Eva stumbled and dropped the tray she was carrying.

children.name: stumble on/over sẩy chân trên
examples: ▪ Mason headed towards the house, stumbling on the rough ground.

children.name: lose your balance
children.definition: to fall or nearly fall, when you need to balance carefully to remain in an upright position, for example when you are standing on a ladder or riding a bicycle:

children.name: mất thăng bằng
examples: ▪ I tried to help Gina up, but I lost my balance and we both fell into the stream.
▪ Bill was leaning over to watch, and lost his balance.

children.name: lose your footing
children.definition: to lose your balance because your foot slips, especially when you are walking or climbing over an uneven or slippery surface: mất thăng bằng
examples: ▪ I lost my footing on the snowy bank and fell into the river.
▪ A climber who lost his footing was taken to hospital with serious injuries.

children.name: to fall through the air to the ground
fall
children.definition: ngã
examples: ▪ One of the climbers fell fifty feet.
▪ A light rain was falling.

children.name: fall out/into/from etc ngã khỏi, ngã vào, ngã từ
examples: ▪ She opened the cupboard and everything fell out.
▪ There should be spaces between the boards of the deck to allow debris to fall through.
▪ Fred fell out of the tree and broke his arm.
▪ The girl had fallen from a fourth-floor window, but was not badly hurt.

children.name: fall on ngã lên
examples: ▪ Careful that box doesn’t fall on you, Charlotte!

children.name: fall off
children.definition: to accidentally fall from something in a high position to the ground: ngã xuống đất
examples: ▪ Jim was laughing so hard he fell off his chair.
▪ A bag of groceries fell off the table onto the floor.

children.name: plunge
children.definition: to suddenly fall a long way from somewhere high up: phóng xuống
examples: ▪ The aeroplane’s engines failed and it plunged into the ocean.

children.name: plunge off/down/into etc phóng khỏi, phóng xuống, phóng vào
examples: ▪ Their car swerved to avoid a truck, and plunged off the cliff.

children.name: plunge to your deathfall a long way and be killed lao mình tìm chết
examples: ▪ A skydiver plunged to his death yesterday when his parachute failed to open.

children.name: plummet
children.definition: to fall from somewhere high up, very quickly and very directly: lao thẳng xuống
examples: ▪ The rope snapped, causing the climber to plummet several hundred feet down the mountain.
▪ Two aircraft on a training flight collided and plummeted to the ground.

children.name: drop
children.definition: to fall suddenly from a high place straight down onto or towards the ground: rơi

children.name: drop onto/to/from etc rơi vào, rơi từ
examples: ▪ Two bottles rolled across the table, dropped onto the floor, and smashed.
▪ A few pine cones had already dropped to the ground.

children.name: tumble
children.definition: to fall quickly through the air, rolling over and over: lộn nhào

children.name: tumble down/off/from etc lộn nhào xuống, khỏi, từ
examples: ▪ A little girl tumbled about 30 feet from the window of her family’s third-floor apartment.

children.name: come down
children.definition: if rain, snow etc comes down, it falls heavily: rơi dày
examples: ▪ We can’t go out now -- the rain’s really coming down.
▪ Snow was coming down so thickly I could barely see through the window.
come downphrasal verbLAND
to fall on the ground
_A lot of trees came down in the storm.
_The snow came down during the night.

children.name: to fall off a horse, bicycle etc
fall off
children.definition: to accidentally fall from something you are riding on, for example a horse or a bicycle: ngã khỏi
examples: ▪ He fell off his bike and broke his wrist.
▪ A bolt broke on an amusement park ride, and several children who fell off were seriously injured.

children.name: be thrown
children.definition: to fall off a horse or similar animal because of a violent or sudden movement: ném
examples: ▪ Rodeo riders can suffer appalling injuries after being thrown by bulls and steers.

children.name: be thrown from bị ném đi khỏi
examples: ▪ He broke his neck when he was thrown from a horse.
